q: Which component acts as the central hub that connects and coordinates all parts of a PC?
explain: The motherboard interconnects CPU, memory, storage, expansion, and I/O.

q: Which ATX main power connector is standard on modern desktops?
explain: Modern ATX boards use a 24-pin main power connector.

q: Which motherboard form factor measures 12 × 9.6 inches (305 × 244 mm)?
explain: Standard ATX is 12 × 9.6 inches.

q: Which small form factor board is 6.7 × 6.7 inches?
explain: Mini-ITX is 170 × 170 mm (6.7 × 6.7 in).

q: Which chipset role historically linked CPU to RAM and integrated graphics at high speed?
explain: Northbridge handled the memory controller and high-speed links.

q: Modern PCs typically combine legacy Northbridge/Southbridge functions into what?
explain: A single PCH or CPU-integrated logic replaces the split design.

q: A bus that sends data one bit at a time is called:
explain: Serial buses transmit one bit per lane but at very high speeds.

q: Which interface superseded PATA for internal drives?
explain: Serial ATA (SATA) replaced the older parallel ATA/IDE.

q: PCIe slot sizes are denoted by lanes. Which is the common graphics slot?
explain: Discrete GPUs typically use PCIe ×16.

q: PCIe is backward compatible across versions. Installing a 2.0 card in a 5.0 slot will:
explain: It negotiates the highest mutually supported version.

q: Which describes LGA CPU sockets?
choices: Pins on CPU, holes in socket
Pins in socket, pads on CPU
Zero insertion with pins on CPU
explain: LGA has pins in the socket and lands on the CPU.

q: Which socket type permanently solders a CPU to the board, common in ultrathin devices?
explain: BGA uses solder balls for permanent attachment.

q: RAM used in laptops typically comes as:
explain: Laptops use smaller SODIMMs to save space.

q: RAM is considered:
explain: RAM is volatile and holds active code/data.

q: Which RAM generations are not cross-compatible due to different key notches?
explain: Each DDR generation has unique notch placement and signaling.

q: Which cache level is smallest and fastest, per core?
explain: L1 cache is closest to the execution units and fastest.

q: Virtual memory uses what to extend RAM capacity?
explain: Least-recently-used pages are swapped to disk.

q: Which storage is non-volatile and has no moving parts?
explain: SSDs are solid-state flash storage.

q: NVMe is:
explain: NVMe is a storage protocol leveraging PCIe lanes.

q: M.2 describes:
explain: M.2 is the physical form factor; modules may speak NVMe or SATA.

q: Typical HDD performance depends primarily on:
explain: Higher RPM reduces latency; seek time affects access.

q: Which optical medium has the largest common capacity?
explain: Dual-layer Blu-ray ≈ 50 GB.

q: Which unit is larger?
explain: TB > GB > MB > KB.

q: GHz refers to:
explain: GHz = 10^9 cycles per second.

q: The PSU’s job is to:
explain: It supplies regulated DC voltages (e.g., 12V, 5V, 3.3V).

q: Which rear switch on many PSUs must match regional mains?
explain: Incorrect voltage selection can damage hardware.

q: Why is opening a PSU dangerous?
explain: Large capacitors retain charge even unplugged.

q: Air cooling typically uses:
explain: Fans move air; heat sinks increase surface area.

q: Liquid cooling advantage vs air is often:
choices: Higher efficiency and lower noise under load
explain: Radiators can dissipate heat efficiently with less noise.

q: BIOS/UEFI first runs which diagnostic at power-on?
explain: POST checks hardware and initializes devices.

q: If the system forgets time/date after shutdown, likely cause is:
explain: CMOS battery maintains RTC and settings when off.

q: Flashing the BIOS requires:
explain: Use the correct image and steps to avoid bricking.

q: Front-panel case connectors usually include:
explain: Headers route case buttons/ports to the motherboard.

q: A field-replaceable unit (FRU) is:
explain: FRUs are designed for quick replacement (e.g., HDD, PSU).

q: Smaller devices like smartphones tend to be:
explain: Integration increases; many parts are not field-replaceable.

q: A NIC provides:
explain: NICs enable wired or wireless networking.

q: Integrated graphics typically:
choices: Are on a PCIe add-in card
explain: Integrated GPUs borrow main memory.

q: Which connector powers SATA drives?
explain: SATA drives use the 15-pin SATA power plug.

q: Which statement about PCI vs PCIe is correct?
choices: PCIe is serial and faster; PCI is legacy parallel
PCIe is parallel; PCI is serial
explain: PCIe uses high-speed serial lanes; PCI was parallel.

q: POST beep codes usually indicate:
explain: They signal hardware faults found during POST.

q: A 3.5 inch desktop HDD typically connects via:
explain: Use SATA data cable and SATA power from PSU.

q: Which statement about memory is true?
choices: SRAM flash drives are non-volatile storage
explain: Flash (a form of non-volatile memory) holds data without power.

q: Form factor choice impacts:
choices: Case fit, power connectors, expansion capacity
explain: Different boards require compatible cases/PSUs and offer different slots.
